Award.AwardTitle: How development forms specific function: the highly unusual visual system of diving beetle larvae.
Award.AbstractNarration:
A fundamental question in biology is whether particular genes serve the same function in all animals. Eyes are a good system to address this type of question because there is such a diversity of eye types in the animal kingdom. There are many genes that are known to be important for both vertebrate and invertebrate eye development, but the eye genes that have been studied have only been studied in a very few organisms. So, it remains unclear how specific eye genes contribute to eye diversity. To address this question, the PIs have developed tools allowing them to investigate the development of the functionally complex, image-forming eyes of Sunburst Diving Beetle larvae. The beetle larvae eyes are quite different from the commonly studied fruit fly eyes and, in some ways, are more like vertebrate eyes. In this project, the PIs will compare genes for eye functions in these animals to see what is common and what is different between the two eye systems. The goal of the project is to understand the molecular basis for functional and structural eye diversity. This project will provide opportunities for training high school, undergraduate and graduate students to carry out molecular and physiological research. In addition, monthly outreach activities at the nearby Cincinnati Zoo and Botanical Garden (which houses a large Sunburst Diving Beetle display) will allow the research group to widely disseminate their findings and foster awareness of the value of conducting basic comparative research.

Preliminary data from this research group suggest that many key genes are present in the eyes of beetles and flies, pointing towards fundamental molecular mechanisms of wide interest. However, there are informative differences in regards to when and where key genes are active. To investigate this further, the PIs will analyze tissue-specific gene and protein expression profiles (which is only possible in the very enlarged beetle eyes) and determine when and where key eye development genes are expressed within these eyes. In addition, using a gene knock-down approach in the beetle (Thermonectus marmoratus), developed in the lab, and accompanying state of the art genetic tests in the fruit fly (Drosophila melanogaster), different factors will be functionally dissected to compare and contrast the roles of genes associated with Drosophila eye and photoreceptor specification, photoreceptor function and lens development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A fundamental question in biology is to what extent particular genes serve the same function in all animals, as such knowledge provides insights into central mechanisms of biological organization. Eyes are a good system with which to address this type of question because there is such a diversity of eye types in the animal kingdom. There are many genes that are known to be important for both vertebrate and invertebrate eye development, but by and large, the eye genes that have been studied have only been studied in a very few organisms. So it remains unclear how specific eye genes contribute to the diversity of eye types. To address this question, the investigators have developed tools allowing them to examine the development of the functionally complex, image-forming eyes of Sunburst Diving Beetle larvae (Figure 1). These larvae are efficient visually guided hunters with 4 prominent forward-facing eyes.  Notably, these beetle larvae eyes function quite differently from those of fruit flies, which have been extensively studied in regard to the genetic control of eye development. In fact, functionally the beetle eyes are more similar to vertebrate eyes than those of other compound eyes.  However, they likely evolved from a compound eye ancestor and hence allow for a relatively direct comparison of gene function and developmental processes of functionally diverse eye types.

            One focus of this project has been to study the similarities and differences in early developmental processes between fly eye and beetle larvae eyes. Investigators found that a common developmental plan exists for both eye types.  Key findings here are that both eye organizations develop from a similar precursor tissue, and that very different layouts of eye organizations can arise from such a tissue through relatively few changes.  Key parameters are the number and placement of the earliest differentiating photoreceptors, as well as the number of additional photoreceptors that are recruited for the development of each unit.  The investigators molecular examination of genes that are important for early developmental processes suggest that some of the orthologous genes indeed are expressed in comparable cell types, with knockdowns in the diving beetle larval eyes leading to phenotypes that might be expected from what is known in the fruit fly system. However, there also are interesting differences between these systems. Taken together the investigators' developmental data is consistent with the beetle larval eyes having evolved from a compound eye-like ancestor, with an elaboration of individual units giving rise to the complex beetle larval principal eyes (Figure 2).

            Similarities and differences were found in regard to the lens development of the two systems.  Optically, the lens of any eye has to be precisely crafted and correctly positioned as to allow for image formation.  Investigations into the composition of fruit fly eye lenses when contrasted with those of diving beetles suggested that both lenses are comprised of similar gene products, called cuticular proteins. However, the much simpler fruit fly lenses are contributed to by a smaller number of cuticular proteins than the more complex, bifocal lenses found in diving beetle larval eyes.

            This project's impact includes 14 peer reviewed publications, the majority of which are co-authored by students, and includes a collaborative publication with engineers who build a camera system that was inspired by some of the investingator's work.  The research project was the basis of training 32 undergraduate, eight graduate students, one post-doctoral researcher as well as a research assistant, and we used aspects of our science in a variety of outreach activities that demonstrated the importance of basic science to the general public.
